According to Beatlesbible.com, Can’t Buy Me Love is the first of the Fab Four’s singles to only feature one singer. Written by Paul, originally there were backing vocals that would be heard here and throughout the song done by John and George but they were thrown out after the band simply determined they didn’t need them. The next single released with only one singer, no backing vocals, would be Things We Said Today later that same year. Overall, there are 5 singles that feature the voice of only one Beatle. They are Can’t Buy Me Love, Things We Said Today, She’s a Woman, Strawberry Fields Forever and Revolution.

The version of Can’t Buy Me Love with the backing vocals can be heard on the Anthology 1 album: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nS0Tf7fY4xw

Interestingly enough this song has a little portion that features a drummer different than Ringo. As audio engineer Geoff Emerick recalls:

Perhaps because it had been spooled incorrectly, the tape had a ripple in it, resulting in the intermittent loss of treble on Ringo‘s hi-hat cymbal. There was tremendous time pressure to get the track mixed and delivered to the pressing plant, and due to touring commitments the Beatles themselves were unavailable, so George and Norman took it upon themselves to make a little adjustment…. Thanks to Norman’s considerable skills as a drummer, the repair was made quickly and seamlessly.

This is one of the few songs on the album that was written solely by Paul.

This is the first Beatles song to use the word “friend” to refer to a current romantic partner, something that also appears in “Another Girl” and “I’ll Follow the Sun”.

Arguably, it’s a tender word choice that brings the lover into a place that’s more intimate than any “term of endearment.”
